headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the Q4 2009 Intel Corporation Earnings Conference Call. My name is Christina, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Mr. Kevin Sellers, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed, sir.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Thank you, Christina, and welcome, everyone, to Intel's Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. I'm joined today as usual by our Chief Executive Officer, Paul Otellini; and Chief Financial Officer, Stacy Smith. Our earnings release and updated financial statements were released today at approximately 1:15 Pacific Daylight Time, and can be found on our investor website, www.intc.com.  This quarter, we continued the practice that we started last quarter of posting additional management commentary from CFO Stacy Smith to our investor website. This commentary was posted at approximately 1:30 p.m., Pacific Daylight Time, and contains added detail about our quarterly performance that was previously reviewed, and prepared remarks during our conference call.  As we begin our call, let me remind everyone that today's discussion contains forward-looking statements based on the environment as we currently see it, and as such, does include risks and uncertainties. Please refer to our press release for more information on the specific risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially. If during our call today there are any non-GAAP financial references made, we will post the appropriate GAAP financial reconciliations to our investor website.  So with that, let me now hand it over to Paul for some comments, followed by brief remarks from Stacy. Paul?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Thanks, Kevin. Our fourth quarter results capped a great year of execution and innovation for Intel. We started the year in one of the deepest recessions in our history and emerged from it with better products and technology, driving new demand for computing worldwide. Our restructuring efforts have borne real fruit by improving the operational efficiency of the company, driving relatively good results in challenging times and exceptional results in a stronger market.  The demand picture in the quarter reflected broad-based strength across all regions and all product categories, with notebooks leading the way. Our product mix was also a notable highlight. Demand for our latest generation of processors, both PC and server, was particularly strong providing an ASP uplift in the quarter. Inventory levels remain in good shape, with OEM comp inventories roughly flat quarter-on-quarter and below level of a year ago.  Distributor inventories are down sequentially. The combination of much stronger sell through and lower year-on-year inventory levels gives us comfort that the supply chain continues to operate very efficiently.  Looking across our product segments, servers had a very strong quarter. The value proposition of Nehalem is clearly evident, and we are seeing a demand shift towards the high end of the performance stack, improving average selling prices. Looking ahead over the next three months, we are planning to refresh our entire server product line with the new 32-nanometer Xeon in the single, dual and multiprocessor segments. It is noteworthy to point out that the Nehalem EX, our multiprocessor version, represents the biggest leap in performance in the history of the Xeon brand.  We remain in an excellent position to benefit from the build out of cloud infrastructure, as well as the reconfiguration of existing state centers for power performance efficiency improvements. Our Atom processor business also continues to do very well, both in netbooks as well as in winning new designs for our growth initiatives. Atom design momentum is very strong, with our new Pine Trail platform in over 80 netbook designs. In the embedded space, we now have over 600 Atom-based design wins and over 2,500 design engagements across 230 customers, 93 of which are brand-new customers to Intel.  At CES, we also demonstrated progress with handheld and consumer electronics platforms built around Atom cores that were very well received. We demonstrated for the first time the LG GW990, a smartphone built with our yet to be released Atom Moorestown platform, which was awarded best smartphone of the show. This demonstrates the power of our architecture in bringing an uncompromising computing experience to handheld devices. Expect more meaningful news and announcements around these businesses during 2010.  Our Notebook business was exceptional this quarter, with demand very strong across the globe. We have been carefully preparing for the shift to mobile, and our product strategy is a reflection of that. To further enhance our PC lineup, at CES, we formally launched 27 new processors produced with our leading-edge 32-nanometer process technology, the biggest consumer launch of new processors since Centrino. Our new core processors are the first ever mainstream PC processors to integrate the graphics engine onto the CPU. This is Moore's Law at work, driving increased performance and improved power and form factor characteristics to our new platforms.  Our new graphics engine is notable, and that it offers full HD video, great mainstream gaming and enhanced 3D capability. I'm happy to report that early demand for these products is excellent.  In closing, we had an outstanding quarter and entered 2010 in a very strong position. We have delivered breakthroughs in our product offerings and our competitive positioning through the Tick Tock development model. Our recently launched 32-nanometer process technology is the critical process capability that will not only bring computing to new levels, but also allow us to broadly offer Atom system-on-chips into many new product categories. We are pleased with our current momentum and look forward to an exciting year in 2010. With that, let me turn the time over to Stacy for a few comments.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Thanks, Paul. The fourth quarter was one of our most profitable quarters ever due to a combination of solid execution, the ramp of innovative new products and a healthy consumer market. Fourth quarter revenue at $10.6 billion was up 28% from a year ago, the largest year-on-year percent increase in more than a decade. Our financial results reflect both significant improvements in our cost structure and higher microprocessor average selling prices. The impact of these improvements can be seen in the gross margin percent of 65%, which was up seven points from the third quarter, and is the highest gross margin percent in our history.  In the fourth quarter, we achieved $2.5 billion in operating profit and $2.3 billion in net income. The PC market has recovered nicely, with our microprocessor revenue, excluding Atom, growing 42% since the market bottomed in the first quarter. In the same time period, Atom microprocessors and associated chipsets have grown to $438 million in revenue in the fourth quarter and $1.4 billion for the year. Fourth quarter gross margin benefited from lower inventory write offs, improving costs and our exceptional product lineup as we ramp and sold the first products manufactured on our 32-nanometer process technology. Total inventories increased $450 million due to these new 32-nanometer products.  For 2009, gross margin was 56%, including a 20-point increase from Q1 to Q4. For 2010, we are forecasting continued strong gross margin, with the midpoint of our annual forecast at 61%. As a result of capital we use in achieving efficiencies, we are able to ramp 32-nanometer process technology and still bring down our capital forecast from our expectation at the beginning of the year. Our capital purchases for the year of $4.5 billion is down from our original forecast of around $5.2 billion, and was less than the annual depreciation run rate.  Operating expenses remain in tight control. This is most clearly seen in spending as a percent of revenue. In the fourth quarter, spending for R&D and MG&A as a percent of revenue remained constant at 29% down from 35% in the first quarter, and 32% in the second quarter. The number of employees decreased by 1,000 people in the fourth quarter as a result of planned factory actions announced early in 2009. Revenue per employee for the year is $440,000, the third highest in our history. The fourth quarter of 2009 demonstrates the strength of our execution and business model. Excluding the impact of the $1.25 billion AMD settlement agreement taken in the fourth quarter, operating profit was a quarterly record $3.7 billion, and as a percent of revenue, was 35%.  Total cash investments comprised of cash, short-term investments and debt security trading assets ended the quarter to $13.9 billion, $1 billion higher than the third quarter. Cash flow from operations was more than $3 billion. During the first quarter, we paid the AMD settlement agreement, paid nearly $800 million in dividends and purchased $1.1 billion in capital assets.  For the first quarter, we are forecasting a seasonal decrease in revenue, taking the midpoint of our forecast range to $9.7 billion, a 36% increase from the first quarter of 2009. We are forecasting the midpoint of the gross margin range to decrease four points from the fourth quarter to 61%.  In addition to the impact of the unit decline, the decrease is primarily due to the higher costs associated with the early ramp of 32-nanometer-based products.  The fourth quarter was a strong finish to what turned out to be a good year. The improvements we have made to our cost structure and efficiency levels have led to exceptional financial results in the fourth quarter, and serviced a strong foundation upon which we can build in 2010 as we refresh our product line and ramp 32-nanometer process technology.  With that, let me turn it back to Kevin.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Stacy and Paul. We'll be now happy to take questions. As most of you know, Intel has a large number of analysts that cover our company. Like we did last quarter, and in an effort to include as many of you as we can, we'll be limiting each caller to one question only. If you need clarification on that question, do please ask. We want to make sure we answer your question adequately. But please, no follow ups and no multipart questions. Christina, go ahead and introduce the first question.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Ross Seymore from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Just a question on what your mixed assumptions are for your first quarter and full-year 2010 gross margin guidance.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Let me start with what we saw in the fourth quarter. I think that kind of serves as a baseline to talk about Q1 and 2010. What we saw in the fourth quarter was really a very rich mix. We saw strength across-the-board on our new products, and in particular, what we saw was we took the first production on 32-nanometer we filled from the top. And there was good market acceptance of those products. And so the combination of that led to a rich mix in the fourth quarter. I expect that that comes back down into a more mixed range as we go across 2010. In particular, we'll be bringing out mainstream and value versions of the 32-nanometer products, and that should say that the sales mix gets into a more normal range as we progress across the next several quarters.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: And that will offset any enterprise improving year-over-year?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: From an overall average selling price standpoint for 2010, we're predicting kind of a normal decline year-on-year. Keep in mind, you have lots of things that go up and down. We'll have a rich mix at the beginning as enterprise coming in. But at the end of the day, we do bring pricing down because we see unit growth potential and consumer segment of the market in emerging markets. There's good price elasticity there. So it's kind of consistent with what you've seen from us the last several years. The price comes down and we drive unit growth with that, and that ends up driving incremental gross margin dollars.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Luke with Barclays Capital.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: If you could clarify how you perceive that you would like your inventory levels to trend as you move through the first quarter and through the year. If you could provide any incremental color on the mix of the inventory that seem to move up somewhat in the calendar fourth quarter with your stronger revenue.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: In Q4, it pretty much unfolded as we expected, and as I articulated on the last call, we saw an increase in inventory. It's entirely due to the new 32-nanometer products. If you look at it on a unit basis, it's pretty flat quarter-on-quarter. But we did have the cost associated with 32-nanometer. Those early wafers tend to be pretty high-cost products. And as you have seen us do in prior transitions of new process technology, we pretty quickly build inventory on the new stuff. You saw it in Q4. I expect to build a little bit more inventory in Q1 as I ramp 32-nanometer products. It won't be the same magnitude that we saw this quarter, but it'll be up some. And then it starts looking a little more normal that progresses through the year and relative to demand. But this is what we do as we ramp our new process technology. It's pretty normal. It's consistent with what I was expecting when I started the quarter.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: I think, Paul, you said that your channel inventory was flat in the 50, and then the comment about the OEM inventory. Could you just reiterate that?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: I think I said it was down sequentially, channel inventory is are down sequentially of our product.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: And the OEMs?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Our view is our comps inventories in terms of the hubs and the see through from the hubs that we have suggest that they're roughly flat quarter-on-quarter and well under a year ago.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Tim, If you just step back on this one, when we look across the supply chain, it's a very complex supply chain. So looking at our authorized channel, those inventories are down. We have visibility into OEM inventories and a lot of that is now held in our hubs and what we see in the down channel. So retail and the shipping lines and stuff, what we see is a healthy level of inventory relative to the demand that we see out over the next couple of quarters.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: I'd add two more things, Tim, one is, remember that two of our largest customers have their quarters ending in January. Secondly, Chinese New Year's is a bit earlier this year.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Lipacis.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: You have three quarters in a row of double-digit growth. I just went back to the model, and I guess a lot of people are probably going to be wondering what happens next. You guys talked about the inventories, and I guess my question is can you help us understand what percentage of your revenues do you have visibility, and where you have visibility into the inventories. Can you see pretty much 100% of the inventories at every place that you sell into? And does the release of your products in Q1, the new product cycle in Q1 versus Q3, does that risk changing any kind of customer order patterns?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: The part of your question, what's our visibility into the supply chain, it's not perfect. It's a broad complex market out there. It ranges from emerging markets with small white box players to big MMPs. But I think it's pretty good. We have a fairly sophisticated way to look across and see how much inventory is out there. And relative to what we believe demand is, I think that it's an appropriate level of inventory.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Our distributor inventory, we have 100% visibility. That's about 25% to 30% of our business in units and dollars. And that's the number I gave that was down sequentially. The OEM inventory, we have hub systems with our largest customers representing the vast majority of our OEM volume. So you're dealing with something well above 50% product. I don't know the exact number, but I suspect in the aggregate between OEM hubs and distribution, it's 75% of the numbers that we've got very good visibility into. On the Q1 cycle, we actually moved towards a Q1 refresh cycle quite sometime ago. It was better for our customers. They liked it. They don't want to have a disruption before holiday. It's either in the early summer, late Q2, or it's in January, February. And that works out best for them in terms of inventory management, and gets new products out there for what is becoming a big part of the cycle. That's Chinese New Year's.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Uche Orji with UBS.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Paul, if the way to understand your 2010 outlook, especially those that relates in to gross margins, given the way 2009 played out, what is your sense as to how 2010 seasonality should play out? And especially, if you can touch on corporate spending since we started a flush in Q4, should we anticipate some more spending from corporate in the future?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: I don't know how it's going to play out. Our view, in terms of what we build into the model, our model for 2010, is a normal seasonal year off of a very good Q4. So in general, when you extrapolate that out and do the math, that gets you to double-digit growth year-on-year because of the high peak in Q4 and the trough that you had in the first half of 2009. We're building into our numbers that a modest recovery of corporate purchases of PCs, that is we're not building in anything extraordinary out of that. Just sort of normal return to deployment as the evaluation cycles for the new hardware in Windows 7 gets completed. What we are benefiting from in the second half of the year, and I think we'll continue to benefit from throughout this year, is the extraordinary return on investment that is incurred by deploying new server technologies. The last technology was sort of a 9:1 ROI kind of technology as we deploy the new Xeon products out. It's 15 and 20:1. We think that that is compelling. The power conservation associated with that is compelling. And that's one of the things that gives us an optimism independent of PC refresh in the enterprise for 2010.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: The other part of your question was gross margin seasonality. I'd say it's a typical year from that perspective. We put up the forecast for Q1, 61% as the midpoint of our forecast range. Typically, we would see as second quarter, from a unit standpoint, is going to be seasonally down. That means that typically the second quarter gross margin is going to be a bit below that 61% and then when we get into the second half of the year, my expectation is it's a bit above that 61% and that's how we get to 61% on average for the year.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Freedman with BroadPoint Amtech.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: If we look at your business model when all the efforts being placed on sort of new growth streams of revenue, can you talk a little bit about the impact that you expect us to have on the longer-term operating model and especially on the operating income line?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: I'm going to go through that in quite a bit more detail in the upcoming May investor meeting, so I think I'll save the longer answer for that. I'll just say our expectation is that based on our performance leadership and the software compatibility and the value proposition around IA, that we can grow those businesses with a very healthy product margin, not dilute the overall gross margins of the company. We've run a record of saying that. I think if you look at the two businesses that are of significant size today, they're both consistent with that belief. Our embedded business, the $1 billion-plus business, it's running at product margins that are a little bit ahead of what the rest of our core business runs. Atom in netbooks, we've grown that to be now in a $1.4 billion business for us in 2009. Also the product margin is right in there with the rest of the core business. That's our expectation, and we'll talk more at the investor meeting.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Adam Benjamin with Jefferies.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Just a question on price elasticity. Obviously, in 2009, the end market pricing for PCs came down pretty dramatically, roughly 20% to 30% in some instances. I'm just curious, as you guys plan for 2010, how are you guys thinking about that, driving the elasticity of unit growth that we saw in 2009, and then how it could potentially impact pricing, plus or minus?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: 2009 was a funny year, Adam,because we all went through it and know. The first half of the year, the lights had gone off, right? What we saw over the course of the year was growth particularly in notebooks and some netbooks around consumer purchases. It was not a robust year for corporate purchases. And that alone, that mix shift alone to consumer and away from corporate, was part of the reason you saw PC prices, on average, being lower, dropping faster than you would have ordinarily seen, point one. Point two is that there really wasn't a new refresh cycle in terms of hardware last year. We had versions of our core product line that are out there, but they were extensions of the existing technology. There was nothing really to drive sell up. The new core products we just introduced, the i5 and the i7, have great new technology in terms of the wireless display technology and Turbo, which gives you the performance boost when you need it and power savings when you don't. And I think early excitement on those two product lines gives us some cause for optimism even in consumer space for an improved sell up cycle.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: So it's fair to say that as you guys are planning for 2010, you guys are thinking those two dynamics won a mix shift back to the enterprise of one with new products can drive end market pricing back up and should help you guys drive your ASPs up as well?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Those are mature market comments. On top of that, I think while we continued growth, just like there has been over the last three or four years in emerging markets where the emerging markets outpaced the mature ones. And clearly, in emerging markets, the average selling price of computers is lower than it is in New York City. I think it's important to kind of separate the mix within the segments of the market from the overall mix of our sales. We are refreshing products who were likely to have a nice benefit from that inside of each of the segments, but the drive over the last four or five years, Adam, has been emerging markets growing faster than the mature markets, consumer growing faster than the rest of the market. And there's good pricing elasticity there. It benefits us to bring the price down and fill our technology into those segments.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Manish Goyal with CREF Investment (sic) [TIAA-CREF]

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: My question is on operating expenses. You guys showed good discipline in the quarterly returns in 2009, and when I look at your first quarter guidance of $2 billion for $9.7 billion of revenue, I'm a little bit surprised because it's roughly the same revenue number that you had in first quarter of 2008, yet your operating expenses are $200 million lower. So I just want to understand what changed and why you are not seeing better leverage?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: First off, let me go back to the commitment that Paul and I have made historically. We're still absolutely on the path that over time, we're bringing down spending as a percent of revenue. And I think we have had some good results in the last couple of quarters and our goal over time is, that we're going to continue to do that. When we look at 2010, you can kind of think of our spending in a couple of different buckets. First off, we are making some investments in R&D projects this year. We had five years in a row of year-over-year employment declines. We'll actually grow employment a little bit in 2010, so you haven't seen that from us in a long time, but we have some high return on investment projects. We were going to go make some incremental investments. Secondly, there's a series of things that aren't really related to the employment level that are going to impact the spending level in 2010. One is, the categorization of how we categorize process engineering from year-to-year. Remember, last year it was cost of sales; this year, it's R&D. So that shift happens in kind of a digital fashion, and so that impacts the quarter to quarter lock [ph] that you were doing. We're giving raises, we had revenue dependent spending this year that's going to be higher than last year. So the combination of those two things is really what you're seeing on the spending line. Neither of those changes the commitment that we're getting great results through our focus on efficiency, and we plan to continue to bring that down over time.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Same question for full year, if I look at your first quarter guidance of $3 billion and full year guidance of $11.8 billion, are you suggesting that even if you continue to hire, your operating expenses will remain roughly flat quarterly or is there any other way to think about this?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: I'm not making a specific forecast for any quarter in the year, and I'm not making a specific forecast for 2010. We've articulated the goal as a longer-term goal to bring down spending as a percent of revenue. We've made good progress on that, and we're going to continue to drive it overall, longer-term horizon.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Stacy Rasgon with Stanford Bernstein (sic) [Sanford Bernstein].

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: I think to follow up on that OpEx question from Manish, as I look at the OpEx this quarter, you have guidance net core [ph] (30:26) down a little bit,  but it's still around $3 billion. And you've got total OpEx for the year pretty close to $12 billion, which would imply, it seems like it would imply flat OpEx on an average basis going forward. And this is a case now where you potentially have, like you said, OpEx moving from cost of goods back into R&D. You're building out new businesses that you're not in right now around the mobile space and whatnot. I'm just wondering, is it actually -- if you walk a little bit more through some of your assumptions around the OpEx growth going forward in that number, that makes up the guidance for 2010.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Just so I'm answering the right question, Stacy, is your question on why is it so flat over the course of the year?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Yes. I'm actually wondering why it's not even up a little bit more than it is given you have these other drivers again, unless all of -- with process development moving back into R&D and with new businesses that you're ramping from relatively nascent  [ph] (31:20) amounts today. I'm just wondering why the OpEx growth wouldn't be expected to actually be higher than kind of the flat level that seems to be implied off of the Q1 guidance.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Yes. The OpEx growth, when you kind of think of it over the course of the year, there's a couple of those elements that just gets spread quarter to quarter. So the categorization of the research and development has happened digitally. I failed to mention, we're also picking up Wind River in 2010. That was an acquisition that we did in the back half of last year, so it's kind of spread across every quarter. We do the same way with the profit- and revenue-dependent spending, so it's probably a little flatter than you would expect, and the increase in R&D projects in the scheme of things doesn't move the number that much. And we are, as we have been, we're finding efficiencies in other places that offset some of that. So when you kind of take all that alchemy together, you end up  with a number that's kind of flattish quarter by quarter by quarter.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: And you don't need to build like any more SG&A to start selling more into the mobile space, for example, with the new Atom applications?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: No, our finance group is so efficient we can sell a lot more than we are today. They're efficient as well [indiscernible] (32:36).

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Glen Yeung with Citi.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Can you guys quantify how much ASPs were up in Q4 and how much you expect them to be down in Q1? And then what's normal ASP decline for a year?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: I can do it at some level of precision because all of those hit the gross margin reconciliation. And so if we start with Q4, you just kind of think about the gross margin in Q4, the increase we saw. The ASP accounted for about two points of that increase. When we think about over the course of 2010, I'm showing you my 2010 gross margin reconciliation versus 2009, that I think the decline in ASP is worth about two to three points, and I'd say that order of magnitude is pretty normal. And Q1'll be a small step on the way, I think, in the gross margin recon. You'll see that, that's worth about half a point down in the first quarter.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Just to clarify now, if you say it was worth two points in a quarter of gross margin, does that imply that the average ASP was down 2%?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: It was up in [indiscernible] (33:53)

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: At the same magnitude is how I should read that?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: We all struggle to say that we're  up [ph] (34:00) because we don't see that at all [indiscernible] (34:01) because of the phenomenon we said. I think you can work through the gross margin math on that. You'll come up with something a little different than 2% to 3%, but the gross margin was up.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Paul and Stacy, I guess I want to revisit the mix question for this year. With your guidance in 2010, we'll see normally as p degradation [ph] (34:33), you kind of have some tailwinds that should be helping you. Consumer moves to corporate, you've got the server cycle, you can make the argument that you have a more robust CLV product line this year, and you've got the introduction of Dales [ph] (34:46). And so I'm kind of struggling with why this wouldn't be a better than average selling price year. Is this sort of an implication that Atom re-accelerate to the percent of the mix, or can you help me reconcile what I see as more tailwind than headwinds on ASPs?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Okay. I'll try and give you some color on that, John. I'm not sure I can fill in all the holes. We're all guessing, no one knows for sure. As I said earlier, we're not programming into our guidance or our estimates any kind of overnight recovery of the corporate market. I think for a variety of reasons that will start coming back, but able to come back based upon eval cycles, qualification cycles and IT shops. And then as corporate budgets open up, they have to decide whether they want to first buy PCs or servers in terms of IT equipment. And we really haven't seen enough so far, except the server run-up in the second half, to be confident on when and what the rate of corporate PC refresh would be, although we have built some into this. Number two, in terms of Atom, we've now been at this for 18 months, a little bit more than that, and up to this point in time, now with all that data, we have not seen any meaningful cannibalization of the notebook market by netbooks. Netbooks look to be for, 90% of them are clearly additive and they're clearly going into market segments that were unaddressed prior to this. In the first 18 months of the netbook, most people who bought them were buying them as incremental machines or travel companions, principally in mature markets or tier one cities of emerging markets. I think that in 2010, you'll start seeing that phenomenon move into emerging markets. And as that does, there may be a slightly higher mix of Atom, but it certainly wouldn't be cannibalistic to our notebook business. And so we're kind of playing all these together in a stew and saying, this is how we see the year coming out.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sumit Dhanda with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Stacy, a question for you. On the 32-nm products or the new architecture products that really helped your selling prices in the fourth quarter, I guess was that the primary driver for ASPs within the client group given that the volumes were likely not very large, or did your older 45-nm generation products also help the ASPs? Did you sell much higher mix within the 45-nm products?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Within the client group, it was, I'd say, a mix of both, but the 32-nm effect was pretty pronounced. As Paul said in his prepared remarks, we've brought out dozens of new products across the client on 32-nm. The way we plan our manufacturing is, we kind of started the manufacturing at the highest in first and worked our way down. We're still working our way down into the mainstream and value price points. So that was a pretty pronounced impact in terms of the mix that we sold in Q4.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Despite the fact that this wasn't a big volume component of what you sold within the client business?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: It was a not insignificant component of what we sell. We ramp these factories pretty fast. You can see it in our inventory results, and you can see it in our sales mix. Or I can see it in our sales mix, we don't show it to you.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Your next comes from the line of Jim Covello with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Can you give us some estimate of what you're going to do with factory loadings in Q1 and Q2?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Probably not at the level of granularity that you're hoping for, but I'll give you a sense. And then this is another one where in May, we're pretty specific, and we'll show you kind of quarter by quarter utilizations, as well as the forecast going into the future. We're in the sweet spot of loading. We're running nicely full. We have the ability to respond to some upsize. We always want to have some of that, but we're full to the point that we're getting really good cost results. I'd expect that to be the norm for this year.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Graham Tanaka with Capital Management.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Just a little bit more on the 32-nm ramp. Pretty fast, I just get a feel for what proportion of sales might have been 32 and more importantly, what that might be by the end of the year. And it seems to me that, that is probably one of the more important reasons for both the sales ASPs going up in the margins, is the 32 ramp being faster than expected, the higher utilization. Is that true?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: I wouldn't say it's faster than expected. We expected it to be pretty fast and beyond that, I'll punt on that one as well and we'll deal with it. We'll show you that data in May when we have the investor meeting.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Berger with FDR Capital Market.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Can you just explain why the first quarter gross margin guidance was 61% and then the year is also only 61%, and any other color around that?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: I apologize in advance because, I think, to explain Q1, I have to explain Q4 and explain the year. I've kind of had to go through a walk, so if you'll bear with me, Craig, I'll do that. Q4 came in, several of the elements as we expected. We did see good news associated with the qualification for sale of 32-nm products, as well as sell through of some of the previously reserved material there. That was about two and a half points of the increase we saw in Q4. We got the good news that we are expecting in CPU volumes. They were seasonally up in the quarter. We got the good news we were expecting in lower excess capacity and, in fact, our excess capacity charges have now gone to zero for the quarter, which we haven't been there since the end of last year. The places where it was a little unexpected is, the bump we saw in CPU ASPs. That was a couple of points of good news that I wasn't expecting when I first set the forecast, and it was a little better in terms of unit costs, and I expected not a lot, but a little. Then if you move into Q1, the drivers that take us from 64% down to 61%, first --  65%, it's even hard for me to say that as an all-time record, 65% down to 61%. The first is, we're going to see some higher CPU cost. This is very consistent with what I showed you at the Investor meeting last May. Those first wafers coming off of 32-nm as we're loading the factories tend to be pretty expensive. That's what ended up in inventory, that's what ships out in Q1, that's going to drive a little bit of a cost increase and then we kind of come down as we go through the year. So very consistent with what I showed you there. And it's a seasonally down quarter from Q4, so we get a little bit of downward pressure as a result of lower CPU sales volumes. And then I do expect in Q1, my mix is a little less rich than what I sold in Q4, that's about half a point. So that's how you get to the 61%. I'll pause there and see if that makes sense, and then I'll take you through the year so I don't get too far ahead of you. In a previous question, I kind of gave what I expected to be the shape of the year. We started 61%, Q2 tends to be seasonally down, so I expect that to be down some from 61%. Then if you do the math, you'd say that we're forecasting a second half gross margin that's something above 61%, in the low sixties. And I think the debate you and I will have at some point is, why is that in the low sixties versus in the mid-sixties? And it really comes back to the conversation we've been having on ASP. A lot of things go right to get us into that low sixties. We've got unit costs coming down, relatively benign period in terms of other cost of sales, so we don't have significant start-up costs or excess capacity charges or anything like that. Paul articulated, we're anticipating a robust unit growth that keeps the factories pretty full. But we are anticipating that pricing comes down some from where we are today, and that brings us down a couple to a few points over the course of the year.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: And then just a follow-up on the tax rate, is 30% of the long-term go-forward that's higher than it used to be?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Suji De Silva with Kaufman Bros.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Just a follow-up on that question on gross margin, what could make your 61% assumption for the year conservative? What are some of your assumptions that might be able to upside there just to understand the level here?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: First of all, we have to put 61% in perspective. 61% is a great gross margin. It says a lot of things are going right for us, so I don't want to jinx this by talking about what has to go from a great gross margin to a perfect gross margin, if you will. The forecast is assuming declining unit costs. It's assuming that we're in kind of the benign cycle in terms of start-up costs and other cost of sales, assuming good volume growth. So all that's baked in. We see also just continued great performance out of factory network from a productivity and an efficiency standpoint, and that helps our costs. If you wanted the scenario that would take us higher than that, it would be a flattening out of the ASP curve or a richer mix, or more units than what we have baked in. And likewise, I can come up with a list that takes me into the lower end of the range, where we have a less rich mix or the unit growth isn't as robust as we thought, and our factories aren't as full.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of  Gus Richard with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: I'm just curious, can [ph] (45:50) you talk a little bit about the carriers, the channel. And as you're thinking about upside to the year, may that play a factor in -- sorry, it's the second part. Do you feel comfortable you're going to have enough capacity?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: The carriers of channel has been around for a while in notebooks, and it wasn't -- it's good, but it's not explosive. What we saw in netbooks in the fourth quarter, last three or four months of the year, was carriers became a very significant portion of the volume of netbooks, probably in the range of quarter of them, 25%. And what we're seeing -- what led me to my comments earlier about netbook growth in emerging markets was really based upon our view that the carrier model will be very efficient in those markets because there's a low entry price subsidized model just like cell phones are, and you get the PC and the bandwidth the same time. So I think that's likely to be a good piece of the netbook business, a growing piece of the netbook business over the course of 2010. In terms of upside, we built a pretty significant growth in that into the numbers that are ready. So I don't know that there'd be much upside there. Secondly, in terms of capacity, no, I don't see any issues on the horizon. We're planning for a very high end of a robust growth from a capacity standpoint in terms of the wafer starts that we need to put in place. And even then, we have time to make some incremental decisions for the, say, fourth quarter '10 kind of volumes over the course of this year. So we'll watch the first half of the year and then make the calls, but right now we believe we have enough buffer capacity coming on, particularly on the 32-nm ramp, and we have the older 45-nm lines still intact to be able to handle virtually anything I can imagine being thrown at us.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brendan Furlong with Miller Tabak.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: A question on the embedded flash other Intel architecture, if you could give some color on what your expectations are for 2010? And you mentioned 600 design wins, what's your expectation of time from design win to revenue with all those new design wins?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Let me speak to design wins and Stacy'll tell you what he thinks is in the Embedded and other directional app [ph] (48:44) . Typically, there's no such thing as an average design win in Embedded. But typically, it's sort of a year to 18 months from initial conversation to production, and we are -- and along the way in that initial conversation, you end up closing the design maybe a third of the way through that. And then these units tend to run for multiple years, in some cases, 10 years. We're not projecting, our Embedded business has grown at double digit percent the last three years. It will continue to, I think, outgrow the company in terms of revenue. But I'm not going to give you a precise number.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Your last question comes from the line of Hans Mosesmann with Raymond James.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: A question about the transition of Wesmere as it replaces [indiscernible] (49:52), how quickly can we see the crossover there in terms of units? And if you can also explain that with regard to Pine Trail over the existing Atom.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: I think on the first part of the question, Hans, Stacy already answered that we are not in the position to stray [ph]  (50:12) that number today, and we'll show you in gruesome detail at the analyst meeting in a couple of months. But what we're doing with this cycle, in general, is using the technology to move 32-nm into the mainstream more quickly than we did the 45-nm. And the rate of crossover between 32-nm and 45-nm will be more a function of second half demand in total than capacity planning to cut one off versus the other. If demand is red-hot, the transition will be slower even though we'll ramp 32-nm as fast as possible. And if it's less red-hot, it'll be slower. In terms of Pine Trail, I think we'll move pretty quickly to transition to that.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: I want to thank everybody for joining the call today. As a reminder, our Quiet Period for the first quarter will begin at the close of business on February 26, 2010. Our first quarter earnings conference call is scheduled for Tuesday, April 13, 2010. Thank you, all. Goodnight.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-14-2010
componenttext: Thank you for your participation in today's conference. This concludes the presentation. You may now disconnect. Have a great day.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the Q1 2010 Intel Corporation Earnings Conference Call. My name is Chanelle and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Mr. Kevin Sellers, VP of Investor Relations. Please proceed, sir.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Thanks, Chanelle. I think we had some background noise. I hope that was taken care of. Thank you, Chanelle. Welcome, everyone, to Intel's First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. I'm here with Paul Otellini, our President and CEO; and Stacy Smith, our Chief Financial Officer. A few important items before we begin. First, we posted our earnings release, CFO Commentary and updated financial statements to our Investor website, intc.com, for anyone who still needs access to that information. Also, during this call, we use any non-GAAP financial measures or references, we will post the appropriate GAAP financial reconciliations to our website as well. Following brief prepared remarks from both Paul and Stacy, we'll be happy to take questions. As we begin, let me remind everyone that today's discussion contains forward-looking statements based on the environment as we currently see it, and as such, does include risks and uncertainties. Please refer to our press release for more information on the specific risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially. One final note, we've scheduled our annual Investor Day on May 11 at the Intel headquarters here in Santa Clara. We look forward to seeing many of you here. If any of you need additional information about that event, please contact Intel Investor Relations directly. So with that, let me now hand it over to Paul.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Thanks, Kevin. A year ago at this time, the industry was in the midst of a sharp correction with many expecting it to continue for an extended period. We saw signals of the bottoming then, and now a year later, the industry has nearly fully recovered. At Intel, we focused on expanding our Nehalem architecture, getting our 32 nanometer process technology ready and the designing alternatives and derivatives of our new Atom processor for many new market segments. As a result of that focus , we started this year with the best product lineup we've ever had with leadership in all segments and categories. Demand for these new products has been incredible and as a result, Intel achieved a record first quarter in revenue and in operating income. It was notable this quarter the demand for our higher end PC products was particularly strong, which helped improve margins and profitability. Our Mobile business set a new revenue record as demand for notebooks continues to be excellent. We're also seeing signs of corporate demand returning, which we believe will continue to improve given the age of the corporate PC fleet and the compelling ROI that our new generation observers presents. Looking at the supply chain, we continue to see aggregate inventories operating within normal, healthy ranges. Intel's own inventory remains lean. OEM inventories are flat quarter-on-quarter and downstream channel inventories are also within normal ranges. We watch inventory levels and sell-through activity very carefully and we remain comfortable with the supply chain conditions. In our manufacturing environment, our factory teams have executed the ramp of our 32 nanometer process superbly. We exceeded output expectations with lower costs than originally anticipated and are currently shipping over 50 SKUs on 32 nanometers. 32 nanometers is our fastest ramping process ever, and I'm pleased to note that we are accelerating the ramp of our third and fourth 32 nanometer factories faster than our original plan, such that by early Q4, we will have four factories in production on 32 nanometers. Lastly, we were excited about our next generation of processors codenamed Sandy Bridge. We began volume sampling in Q1, shipping thousands of samples to a broad range of customers and are planning for volume production later this year. As we look forward, we are optimistic about the prospects of our business for the rest of 2010 and beyond. Our product portfolio, combined with our excellent execution and the ongoing benefits from restructuring, have us positioned for continued profitable growth. This is a great way to begin 2010 and I look forward to seeing many of you here in May for our Investor Meeting, where we will talk in more detail about how we plan to build on this momentum and further exploit the growth opportunities before us. With that, let me turn the meeting back over to Stacy.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Thanks, Paul. The strength in our business model can be seen in the first quarter results. Record first quarter revenue of $10.3 billion resulted in record first quarter operating profit of $3.4 billion and cash flow from operations of approximately $4 billion. This better-than-expected financials resulted from strong sales of our new products. Microprocessing unit sales declined slightly less than seasonal and average selling prices for microprocessors were up slightly quarter-on-quarter. Supply chain inventory levels appear to be healthy after several quarters of replenishment. The Mobile Computing segment was particularly strong with customer demand for our new products leading to an increase in mobile microprocessor average selling prices and record mobile microprocessor revenue. First quarter gross margin of 63.4% was higher than our expectation. The factory network performed well in the first quarter, ramping 32 nanometer process technology, controlling costs and reacting quickly to meet customer demand. The first quarter demonstrates the impact of our work and improving our cost structure. Spending was 30% of revenue and operating profit of $3.4 billion was 33% of revenue. The number of employees was approximately flat in the first quarter with revenue per employee of $129,000, the third highest in our history. Moving to the balance sheet, total cash investments comprised of cash, short-term investments and trading assets, ended the quarter at $16.3 billion, $2.4 billion higher than the fourth quarter. Cash flow from operations was approximately $4 billion. During the first quarter, we paid nearly $900 million in dividends and purchased over $900 million in capital assets. We are forecasting a revenue decrease for the second quarter that is slightly less than our average seasonal decline, taking the midpoint of our forecast range to $10.2 billion, a 27% increase from the second quarter of 2009. We are forecasting the midpoint of the gross margin range to increase one point from the first quarter to 64%. For 2010, we are now forecasting a record annual gross margin with the midpoint of our annual forecast increasing from 61% to 64%. The investments we are making in leading edge process technology, the strength of our product line, a continued focus on our cost structure and strong worldwide demand led to the record results we saw in the first quarter and a record financial results we are forecasting for the second quarter in the year. With that, let me turn it back to Kevin.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Okay, thanks. We're now going to move to Q&A. We'd like to limit each of you to one question and then a follow-up, if you have one. So with that, Chanelle, go ahead and please introduce our first questioner.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Your first question is from the line of John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Stacy, my first question, Q2 gross margins and full year gross margins both being guided to about the same level at 64%. Help me understand the put-and-takes into the back half of the year that prevents you from getting sort of better margin leverage.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Sure. Let me start, John, by giving you just, say, kind of a bit of detail about the puts-and-takes. So first off, first half gross margin a little bit below 64%, 64% for the year. So the math gets you to some modest increase in gross margins in the second half over and above the kind of record gross margin levels that we're achieving in the first half. As I think about the second half, let's first focus on the core business. I expect that to be slightly positive to gross margin. I think that we'll see increase in volume, that helps a bit. We're going to see a decrease in cost, that helps a bit. Offset a little bit by a decrease in average selling prices, kind of a less than what you normally see decrease in volume prices, combination of that makes that slightly positive. I also expect in the second half of this year to have a little bit lower start-up cost environment, so those two things are positive. And then offsetting some of that is an increase in write-offs. We'll be building, as Paul said, the Sandy Bridge product. That's the new microarchitecture that lands on 32 nanometer, so in the context of Tick Tock, that would be the Tock. And as you saw with Westmere, the product that we build prior to qualification for sale will be written off. And so we'll see a little bit of an increase in write-offs in the second half of the year, and that offsets some of the positives that I mentioned.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Paul, my follow-up question, you talked about signs of corporate coming back. Is that just in the Server business where you guys have had some strength for couple of quarters now or are you starting to see on the client side? You give us a little bit more detail, that'd be helpful.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Yes. We saw it on the first quarter where we've seen some real signs of PC purchases, corporate SKUs picking back up again. Some of that was wrapped around our new products, the Arrandale notebook products. But some of that was also just even some of our older SKUs that are just kind of classic running corporate SKUs also picked up. And to me, that suggests that the average fleet of notebooks is four years old out there, the average fleet of desktops is five years old. You're getting to the point where as CIOs are feeling a bit better about their business, it makes economic sense to swap these out just from an ongoing cost of ownership standpoint.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Glen Yeung with Citi.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Could you address a little bit the supply condition that you face both front end and back end, particularly as we move into the back half of the year and demand normally picks up?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: The Intel supply?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: We're ramping the 32 nanometer factories as fast as we can and faster than we first expected. In fact, in the first quarter, we ended up shipping more 32 nanometer microprocessors than we first planned, principally driven by demand for those products and I guess the overall health of the business environment in general, which was not planned a quarter ago. Looking forward, we'll use a combination of the four 32 nanometer factories and our existing 45 nanometer factories to be able to satisfy, I think, almost any demand scenario you could imagine out there. In terms of other people's supply, which is what I thought you were hinting out at first, I really don't see any fundamental constraints. If I look at all the pieces, the components that go together in terms of memory, and screens, and batteries and so forth, that would retard the industry's ability to meet almost any demand scenario.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Stacy, maybe for you, the cash levels that you're at now, you're not that far off of your records, which I think were set back in 2004. Particularly with no change in CapEx, any thoughts about -- and I assume cash are going keep on growing, any thoughts about uses of cash?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Yes, you're absolutely right. The strength of our business, as Paul said, surprises the strength of cash generation was also surprising. But what you should take from the fact that we've been doing minimal buybacks over the last year is that we're growing our cash balance. Frankly, we're looking at some strategic investments and evaluating those in that context. We're growing the cash balances and we're comfortable with the levels of cash we have. The priority in terms of capital structure in terms of returning cash to the shareholders is the dividend. You saw us increase that in Q4. We've had multiple years where we've increased the dividend without fail. And just putting it in context from 2006, I think, our dividend per share was about $0.40 per share. Based on the increased we just did, we're at $0.63 per share, so a nice increase in the dividend over time and that continues to be the priority.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Chris Danely with JPMorgan.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: On the end markets and demand trends, it sounds like consumer was very strong in Q4 and then corporate kind of kicked in Q1. When you talk to your customers, what do you expect, what do they expect in terms of demand trends between corporate versus consumer for the rest of the year? And what will be the implications for your business?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Well, you're right. Consumer has been the driver, I think, throughout this cycle not just in the fourth quarter of last year. But I think I talked last year about China in particular in the early part of last year, and then the United States and Europe in the second half of last year. I think the overall shift to mobility is one of the mega trends that's out there, both in the consumer standpoint and in the corporate standpoint. The first quarter and even our first half numbers, I think are buoyed by a combination of things, that's a very healthy China and Chinese New Year scenario. I think the new products we've launched have a pretty compelling pull at the end market level, simplified branding, lots of really good features, et cetera. And lastly, now you're to starting to see some corporate PC purchases re-emerge. I'm still not going to go out on a limb and our customers certainly aren't going to go out on a limb and say, "There's a corporate refresh snapback coming." I think what we see in this cycle is much more people are buying things to replace older machines because it's just cheaper. And they're doing that on their budgets as they free up a bit more money here and there. I think they'll also make the trade-offs between PCs and servers and software as they go forward. And right now, hardware seems to be doing pretty well on that trade-off.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: So Stacy, if you plug in the gross margin guidance, it sounds like your gross margin in the second half of this year is going to get back to the peak of last year in Q4. Should we consider that 65% a peak number? And if you guys have some more higher write-offs at the end of this year, is that a good thing for next year, when the write-offs being lower next year in the Tick Tock model?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Two very different questions. So in terms of the gross margin forecast for this year at 64%, that's an annual record. You're right, we're likely to have some quarters above that. I think you're really asking, "Does it change my long-term view of the kind of gross margin profile of the company?" If you hearken back to a year ago, as Paul says, the depth of the reception when we were down in the mid-40s, I articulate this normal range to be in between 50% and 60%. I think we spent one quarter in that normal range and then we've been above it every quarter since. And this year, it looks like we'll be above it every quarter. On that question, I think I'll defer answering it until we get to the Investor Meeting. I think that's a much better platform for talking about how we're looking at longer-term gross margin trends. To the more tactical part of that, there'll be lots of puts-and-takes to the H1 '11 gross margin. But yes, you would expect to see that the inventory that we write off prior to qualification for sale, assuming that, that ends up being sellable inventory, will be a benefit to gross margin where we get into the subsequent quarters. Now that's one of many elements, but that element would likely be positive assuming that, that qualification goes as we expected to and as prior qualifications have gone.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Tim Luke with Barclays Capital.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Paul, in sort of streaming the environment obviously you had several strong quarters, very strong fourth quarters, strong first quarter. You're now guiding for a slightly firmer than seasonal second calendar quarter off a pretty high base. Could you just give us your sense of your feasibility on that slightly better than seasonal guide for the second calendar quarter? And what elements are likely to contribute to that? Is it the PC still the leading? Is it the Servers? Is it all of the above?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: I think it's certainly PC driven, Tim. But I think there's other things that are woven into it. We're still in the very steep part of the ramp on the 32 nanometers, bringing that into the product line. There's still, as I said earlier, a lot of pull for that product. We were slightly behind, quite frankly, satisfying all the demand that our customers wanted on 32 in the first quarter, even though we were producing much more than we first thought. We expect to catch up to that demand in the second quarter on 32 nanometers over the course of the quarter. So I think part of that is just the excitement around the new products on the PC side, number one. Number two, the Nehalem-EX product, which is our new multiprocessor product, began shipping in the last two weeks of the quarter. I think that'll have a full quarter effect. So far, there's something like 30 systems that have been announced and the receptivity and the pent-up demand for that, I think, is very good. So you get a combination of those things, all driven by new products that I think will give us that better than seasonality picture that we're painting.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: As you go into the second half of the year, do you think that you'll be able, given a stronger first half, to sustain what you might frame as normal seasonality broadly for the second half of the year? Or do you think, look, it's been first around the beginning of the year, we should be modeling a slightly lower than seasonal uptick or not given that it sounds like you think corporate's going to back?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: I think we won't talk about the second half at this point in time, except to say that we're putting in place sufficient capacity to handle, as I said earlier, virtually any demand scenario you could imagine. We're assuming continued growth in units over the course of the year. We're going to be ramping 32 nanometers as fast as possible. So the only question that we have in the supply standpoint is how much 45 we keep on, and what's our assembly test loading capabilities. And we'll put some buffer in those to make sure that we've got sufficient capacity.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: So better than seasonal possibly just given your focus on capacity rather than...

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: I didn't go there, Tim.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Kevin Cassidy with Thomas Weisel.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Could you describe the mix in the Servers? Was that a richer mix and just lower units?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: In Q1?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: The mix is a little less rich than Q4, and I think that there's a couple of things that going on there. First is, that we saw a pick up in what we call the transactional business. This is tempt to be uniprocessor servers based on the Nehalem parts that are sold by both the channel and our OEM customers typically into a small and medium business environment. So I think that's a good sign and we haven't seen that kind of demand profile before in the transactional volume, at least not in the last half of 2009. The fact that, that came back was one of the positive signs and is leading us to the guidance we gave for Q2. And then we also, I think, there was some -- as people moved towards the transition of the older multiprocessing lines to the newer multiprocessing line, they basically thin down their inventories in anticipation of the launch of the EX, and now we'll have a full quarter to ship in Q2 with that product line.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: You had mentioned that corporate demand coming back on the client side. Do you see that as a lagging from the servers strength you saw in fourth quarter, or are they not related?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Well, I'd like to think that people are looking at these things with a clear economic eye. And if you look at it with a clear economic eye, you refresh the servers first. That builds our infrastructure up, that gives you the fastest return on investment. You probably can squeak out another quarter or so with your PC fleet. And I also think that corporations are likely to deploy Win 7, so that people have to qualify that and get the SKUs ready, and I think that's what's happening now. So I don't think it was really a lag effect. I tend to think it was much more of clear view what the return on investment was, versus the cost savings that replaced in the PCs that you're now seeing a bit more latitude on.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Hans Mosesmann with Raymond James.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Question on Notebook mix. Has the netbook dynamic kind of slow down or saturated as a percentage of total Mobile?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Well, it depends on the granularity of the question. If you look in terms of the total year last year and our view for the total year this year, we really don't see a change. I think we suggested that netbooks seem to be settling out at about 20% of the mobile form factors, and on an annual basis, that looks to be about right. And I would expect pretty significant year-on-year growth in the Netbook business. I think that netbooks in general have become -- though they are by definition, a consumer purchase, there is no corporate netbook market that we found. And it was pretty robust in the fourth quarter. You had a lot of new entrants coming to the marketplace, large companies really coming into the first time. And I think that seasonality plus maybe a bit of the overhang from a number of players coming in the fourth quarter is what we saw in Q1 where Atom was down a bit more than what we would normally see as seasonal.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: What's the company position with tablets? It seems to be a big category, emerging category. What's your strategy there?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: At this point, I'd view tablets much like I viewed netbooks two years ago, that was a new category then that was market expensive. I think tablets will also be a new category that will likely be market expensive. If I look forward over the course of the year, particularly at Computex coming up in the first week of June, we have a lot of our customers announcing new tablet form factors around Atom, around Moorestown versions of Atom. And their support for a multitude of operating environments, you'll see products on Android, on Windows 7 and on MeeGo.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Mark Lipacis with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: The clients business was flat, and I think if you look at least the couple of the larger North American PC OEMs, it seems like the forecast for their client business is to decline a bit in the first calendar quarter. So I guess there's different ways to potentially explain that. Maybe they see upside like you guys did, maybe they're building or replenish inventories, or there's another set of OEMs that are perhaps benefiting from the growth dynamics. Can you share with us your thoughts about how we might think about that difference in expectations?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: We'll, I don't know that I can help you a lot there, except to say that we were down. So I mean, I'm not sure that I followed how much their client business is forecasted to be down versus what you guys are doing, but our business was down. It was better than seasonal but down.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: On a unit basis, market was probably closer to -- it was slightly better than seasonal but not dramatically better. The benefit we really saw in the first quarter was in the mix and the price.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: And then on the Data Center business, you gave some answers to that, but what would be a normal 1Q for that business?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: What you saw was pretty in line with what we would normally expect, in terms of Data Center Group normal seasonality.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: It's typically down about 8%.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Yes, and that's 8% to 9%. That's right where we were.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Jim Covello with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Last quarter, you were good enough to break out for us the change in unit inventory versus the change in dollar inventory. I was wondering if you could do that again for us this quarter. You said you wanted to build some inventory, but you weren't really able to build much.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: Yes, I'll be happy to help though, Jim. And yes, the way you characterize it is the way I see it. Because of the increases we saw over the course of the quarter and demand on the new mobile platform, Arrandale, I wasn't able to get as much inventory in place as I hoped. If you look at it between dollars and units, what you see is units are up a bit more than dollars, but still not as much as I'd want as we kind of move into the second quarter, and based on the strength that we're seeing and the ramp of these new products. If you deconstruct the inventory between the processes, what we saw is more than 100% of the increase in inventory and more than 100% of the increase in units was on 32 nanometer. So we got a little bit in place there, and everything else was down. And as I think about Q2, my hope is that I can build some inventory into the second quarter, in anticipation of a second half that's higher.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-13-2010
componenttext: And for my follow-up, I mean, I guess you guys have kind of started off the year believing that we were looking at sort of a mid-teens PC kind of year. If I put any kind of close to normal seasonality in your revenue in the back half of the year, you'd be up well into the 20s. It certainly doesn't seem like you're out shipping demand because there's nowhere in the supply chain that's building any inventory.
